title: In July 2018, how will the Chinese renminbi rank as an international payments currency according to SWIFT?
preds:

Remember that per the most recent Clarifications entry, we're using the "domestic and international payments currency" chart, which is the data set equivalent to the only data that was given in the charts back when the question was opened. So, for June 2018:
#3 is the pound, holding about even (7.29% June, 7.31% July, 7.05% Aug, 7.43% Sept, 7.71% Oct, 7.42% Nov, 7.07% Dec, 7.26% Jan, 7.34% Feb, 7.09% Mar, 7.41% Apr, 7.45% May, 7.44% June).
#4 is the yen, after going up a itty-bit (3.16% June, 3.15% July, 3.01% Aug, 3.10% Sept, 2.92% Oct, 2.62% Nov, 2.96% Dec, 2.80% Jan, 3.29% Feb, 3.50% Mar, 3.47% Apr, 3.54% May, 3.60% June).
#5 is the renminbi, after losing just a bit of share (1.98% June, 2.00% July, 1.94% Aug, 1.85% Sept, 1.46% Oct, 1.75% Nov, 1.61% Dec, 1.66% Jan, 1.56% Feb, 1.62% Mar, 1.66% Apr, 1.88% May, 1.81% June).
#6 is the Canadian dollar, after an up in share (2.04% June, 1.82% July, 1.75% Aug, 1.86% Sept, 1.60% Oct, 1.57% Nov, 1.57% Dec, 1.51% Jan, 1.57% Feb, 1.70% Mar, 1.71% Apr, 1.64% May, 1.77% June).
#7 is the Australian dollar, after an up in share (1.47% June, 1.62% July, 1.50% Aug, 1.50% Sept, 1.43% Oct, 1.38% Nov, 1.39% Dec, 1.38% Jan, 1.48% Feb, 1.48% Mar, 1.45% Apr, 1.42% May, 1.51% June).
#8 is the Hong Kong dollar, also up in share (1.28% June, 1.26% July, 1.32% Aug, 1.30% Sept, 1.14% Oct, 1.45% Nov, 1.22% Dec, 1.32% Jan, 1.31% Feb, 1.33% Mar, 1.28% Apr, 1.38% May, 1.49% June).
#9 is the Swiss franc, holding about even on share (1.57% June, 1.57% July, 1.63% Aug, 1.62% Sept, 1.63% Oct, 1.58% Nov, 1.26% Dec, 1.42% Jan, 1.64% Feb, 1.43% Mar, 1.54% Apr, 1.34% May, 1.35% June). For the historical series on where the renminbi has been rank-wise since the opening of the question, that's #6 in June, #5 in July, #5 in August, #6 in September, #7 in October, #6 in November, #5 in December, #5 in January, #7 in February, #6 in March, #6 in April, #5 in May, and #5 in June. While the value of the renminbi is down a bit from where it was in early June, it's not down dramatically.  With no news reports of a massive depression having hit this month in China, it seems quite unlikely that the renminbi will have suffered sucha a dramatic decline in value of domestic plus international transactions since June that it'll be #8 when the July data comes out in the August report. It is also essentially certain, given the lack of a depression and stock market crash in Britain, that it will not have shot up past the pound's use in domestic and international transactions to become #3.  Not that it was ever plausible that it would even on the day this question opened.

Confirming. With a week to go in in the key month, the renminbi's recent decline in value stopped right where it was trading last year, when it was #5 in the SWIFT rankings.  Absent a major decline in domestic transactions in China this month that somehow has avoided making the news, there's no way it's fallen to #8.
Readind tea leaves on this one.

People have been talking up recent currency value declines.  So let's look at where the relevant currencies were July 13th versus the dollar compared to May 14, and thus get a sense of what the value change would do to the rankings: The pound is down about 2.5%.
The yen is down about 2.5%.
The renminbi is down about 5.7%.
The Canadian dollar is down about 2.7%.
The Australian dollar is down about 1.5%.
The Hong Kong dollar is about even.
The Swiss franc is about even. So, at the same volumes as May, we would expect the SWIFT percentage share for the renminbi in July to decline a bit compared to the other currencies in the 3-to-9 range, but not enough to actually make it drop a rank from #5 to #6. Now, we also know, thanks to SWIFT, that the renminbi is pretty low volume in cross-border transactions anyway, so a decline in cross-border transactions would have to be unusually severe to seriously move the renminbi's rank down on the "Domestic and International Payments" chart. Thus, the question is, has there been a serious decline in the share of SWIFT-recorded domestic Chinese transactions as a percentage of overall SWIFT-recorded transactions in July compared to May?  Because, given the small size of the currency value decline and the lack of exposure on international transactions, that is the mechanism by which the renminbi could be dragged all the way down from its May rank of #5 to a July rank of #8. (I might actually allocate some percentage to that if I weren't so high above the consensus for a rank of 8+ on my older predictions, given that China wouldn't be eager to announce that it's had a recession.) We'll also note, for the people still giving any percentage to a rank of #1 to #3, that given the known changes in value, the renminbi needs to more-than-double total transaction volume over May in order to get to #3 in July, and needs a whole quadrupling unless there is a massive, like 50%, decline in pound transactions.  You hear anything about a sudden, unexpected massive supercharging of the Chinese economy, or a Great Depression-level collapse in Britain, in the last six weeks?  Zero out your 1-3 brackets, kids, unless you're just trying to make me look good.
Lovely...  Just saw the correction to the clarification.

RMB payments continue rising in absolute terms, but at a significantly lower rate than other global payments as rated by SWIFT. Dropping from #5 to #6 made headlines, but the RMB is unlikely to drop much further, particularly given international investors' view of the future of a global China - e.g. as overseas investors continue to funnel increasing sums into China despite modest returns (see: China A-Shares returns). #4-#7 is a large and fitting range; even if the RMB is bumped up 1 or down 1, it will remain in this range.

SWIFT will release one more report (the July report, giving data for June 2018) before the final one (August, giving data for July) that resolves the question.  But based on past performance, the "July" report might not actually make it out before this question closes on July 31st (the "April 2018" report came out 3rd May 2018, the "November 2017" report came out 1st December 2017). A devaluation could seriously impact the renminbi's share in the rankings because SWIFT measures the currency transactions by value.  If nominal numbers of renminbi traded holds steady but the currency depreciates by 20%, then share declines 20%. So I don't expect a reversal and implementation to be fast enough to seriously impact resolution of this question.

Oh, I just realized there's something going on that people might not have known. What SWIFT reports have called "share as an international payments currency" -- on page 5 of the October report, for example ( https://www.swift.com/file/45006/download?token=6GKon__P ) -- explicitly includes "domestic and cross-border" transactions, not just cross-border transactions. "Domestic" transactions in London as a financial center (like trades on the London Stock Exchange) drive much of the pound's use by SWIFT measures (since the pound is only 3.84% by share as a cross-border currency and the British economy in terms of GDP is much smaller than the Japanese).  The only way the pound sees a massive decline in value-of-transaction-share is if London as a financial center collapses relative to the rest of the international economy.  Even if the pound as a currency declined massively, that wouldn't be enough; things like LSE-listed stocks with large international operations would see their share prices in pounds go up to match the value of their overseas operations, so value-of-trades would not decline as precipitously.  You'd have to see something like LSE-listed multinationals delist themselves and move to other exchanges en masse for some reason.  Or perhaps the detonation of a nuclear bomb in London. The renminbi, on the other hand, doesn't have a major international exchange with companies with large non-Chinese operations listed.  Further, it's not a factor of more than two above #8 the way that the pound is above the yen.  To drop to #8, the a mere 20% decline in the value of the renminbi relative to other international currencies would suffice, assuming nominal domestic volume didn't increase much.  And since the renminbi's not fully liquid in the international market and relatively little-used in cross-border trade (it's only ranked #8 in cross-border currencies, 0.98% by volume), local stickiness of prices and wages should hold at least in the short term, so domestic inflation wouldn't push the nominal volume up quickly. So, for the renminbi to become #3, it takes a sudden, massive, unprecedented end of London as a financial and trading center on the order of months COMBINED with the renminbi climbing rapidly to pass the yen (when it's currently at about half the yen).  For the renminbi to become #8, it takes something as ordinary as its government deciding to goose exports by devaluing its currency moderately, or a medium-sized run by spooked international traders.

In order for the yuan to break into the top 4 currencies for international payments (currently #5), it would have to become more popular than either the dollar, euro, pound sterling, or yen, in an environment where its share of the international payments market has declined from 2.31% in December 2015 to 1.61% in December 2017.  There are inherent disadvantages for the yuan in these comparisons, namely the fact that the People's Bank of China is the most state-regulated of the banks in the upper echelons of these rankings. This is a root cause of why international use of the yuan has declined over the past two years. A specific cause recently was the People's Banks attempts to curb capital outflows and declines in CNY deposits in offshore accounts, particularly in Hong Kong, a massive clearing center for CNY on the international market.  One has to consider the possibility of China's reversal of these policies, the likelihood that one of the "big 4" suddenly implodes or if another "peer" currency, like the Canadian dollar, continues to compete with the yuan. Over the next 5 months, the most likely outcome is that the trends observed continue. CNY will almost certainly remain at #5, possibly #6 if the Canadian dollar continues to improve.

I forecast a 90% that the Chinese RMB will remain between the 4th and 7th rankings as an international payments currency as of July 2018. Further, I estimate a 75% chance that it will remain in its current position of 5th and will not catch the Japanese yen by July. I do believe it will surpass the yen within 18 months, but stands little chance of catching the Pound sterling until the Belt and Road Initiative (BRI) is more fully realized over at least a five year period. The Chinese government is a careful regulator over its financial system, particularly in measures to stem the RMB moving overseas for property and other purchases. Although there are signs of the RMB moving toward a greater share of international payments such as Pakistan announcing the RMB will be used for its bilateral trade and investment with China, and the agreements around the BRI, the Chinese government wants to see and will only allow a gradual and controlled RMB growth.

I think the yuan will most likely stay in the #4-7 range this year because of a slowing Chinese economy and uncertainty about structural economic reforms and regulations to come. However, it may go higher due to the uncertainty of Brexit which could weaken the pound.

That means that the renminbi avoided the #8 slot in October by a mere three hundredths of a point, and is less than a fifth of the share of the current #3.  And it's the only currency that's seen three months of straight decline.  I'm adjusting my forecast fairly sharply in favor of the "More than #7" band on this basis.  We'll see if the renminbi can break out of this slump in the coming months; how much effort will China spend to break the trend?

Increasing #1 - #3 after evaluating Rahul_Kumar data and analyses http://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/616760 , but not going to the extremes here. Or not yet, I want to see more data as time moves toward the July 2018 forecast horizon.

So, anyway, since I was looking it up, long-term baseline data from the SWIFT Tracker (some figures in 2012/2014 possibly off due to straining at poor resolution PDF images): September 2012:  #1 EUR (42.08%) -- #2 USD (31.12%) -- #3 GBP (9.99%) -- #4 JPY (2.46%) -- #5 AUD (2.18%) -- #6 CAD (1.99%) -- #7 CHF (1.83%) -- #8 SGD (1.04%) -- #9 SEK (0.99%) September 2013:  #1 USD (36.85%) -- #2 EUR (36.13%) -- #3 GBP (8.79%) -- #4 JPY (2.49%) -- #5 AUD (1.94%) -- #6 CAD (1.90%) -- #7 CHF (1.64%) -- #8 HKD (1.03%) -- #9 SGD (1.00%) September 2014:  #1 USD (42.97%) -- #2 EUR (29.43%) -- #3 GBP (8.35%) -- #4 JPY (2.74%) -- #5 AUD (2.00%) -- #6 CAD (1.90%) -- #7 CNY (1.72%) -- #8 CHF (1.40%) -- #9 HKD (1.02%) September 2015:  #1 USD (43.27%) -- #2 EUR (28.63%) -- #3 GBP (9.02%) -- #4 JPY (2.88%) -- #5 CNY (2.45%) -- #6 CAD (1.81%) -- #7 CHF (1.62%) -- #8 AUD (1.54%) --  #9 HKD (1.12%) September 2016:  #1 USD (41.08%) -- #2 EUR (31.24%) -- #3 GBP (7.77%) -- #4 JPY (3.53%) -- #5 CNY (2.03%) -- #6 CAD (1.90%) -- #7 AUD (1.57%) -- #8 CHF (1.45%) -- #9 HKD (1.15%) September 2017:  #1 USD (39.79%) -- #2 EUR (33.05%) -- #3 GBP (7.43%) -- #4 JPY (3.10%) -- #5 CAD (1.86%) -- #6 CNY (1.85%) -- #7 CHF (1.62%) -- #8 AUD (1.50%) -- #9 HKD (1.30%) Based on that, it doesn't look like the renminbi is on any rocket ride to me.  It went from irrelevant to a third-tier international payments currency between 2013 and 2014, and has been third-tier ever since.  (The USD and EUR make up the first tier, and the GBP is the second.)  Slipping down down into tier 4 (with the HKD, SEK, SGD, THB) or moving up to tier 2 (competitive with GBP) would likely require an unanticipated "headline news"-level event.  Where it ranks against the other third-tier currencies (Japanese yen, Canadian dollar, Australian dollar, Swiss franc) bounces up and down a bit, so a rank from 4 to 8 is where it should be expected to wind up; 8 would require some "bad luck" but would not be shocking. Of course, that just agrees with my previous analysis, so maybe I'm suffering confirmation bias.
Barring shocks, RMB should continue to lose mkt share as payment currency in the near term. Still comfortably within 4-7 as the pace is likely to be very slow.

The share of the Chinese renminbi as an international payment currency declined for a second straight month in September, sliding down the global list to rank behind the Canadian dollar, according to global financial messaging service provider SWIFT on Tuesday. The ratio has dropped for two consecutive months, down from two per cent in July to 1.94 per cent in August, and then falling further in September “Despite the opening of more RMB clearing centres in markets around the world and inclusion in the IMF’s Special Drawing Rights currency basket in October 2016, the utilisation of Chinese renminbi globally as a payment currency has lost momentum over the last two years.” Still, the SWIFT analysts expected usage of the RMB to increase over time, as China’s Belt and Road Initiative will likely stimulate the need of the Chinese currency in cross-border trade, cash management, financing and investments

First off, there is absolutely no way the renminbi is going to be in the top three currencies in a year. It's usage would have to more than triple in that time and the Chinese financial system is just not plugged in enough to the global financial system to do that. The currency has also fallen back behind the Canadian dollar to sixth. That said, I think the renminbi grows again from here thanks to increasing usage in Central Asia and, more importantly, Southeast Asia.

Major economic upheaval would be required to get into top 3. CNY has slipped a few spots in past few years to 7. Any slow down in Chinese economic development could drop it further. A lot can happen in a year.

I don't think there's any chance of the renminbi (#6, 1.98%) advancing past the pound (#3, 7.29%).  Slipping ahead of the Canadian dollar (#5, 2.04%), sure, the yen (#4, 3.16%) maybe.  I mean, it was ahead of the yen and in #4 for a bit in 2015.  But the #3 slot would require a big hit to the pound AND a big boost to the renminbi. On the other hand, I think there's a reasonable chance that the renminbi (#6, 1.98%) could slip behind the Swiss franc (#7, 1.57%) and Australian dollar (#8, 1.47%); not a huge chance, but within the bounds of reasonable possibility. (Ranks and percentages given for the currencies for June 2017 from SWIFT's July 2018 RMB Tracker Special report, https://www.swift.com/file/43176/download?token=2X-MP8Kr )

Which competes against it for 4th?  Even with a messy Brexit, financial relationships with the pound will take a while to unravel.  Also, North Korea and its shenanigans make investors leery of China.  Lastly, China's recent internet censorship crackdown has the effect of dissuading RMB transactions.
Hard to believe that it will pass the US dollar, the Euro or the Pound so top three is out. Small chance it will drop further.
